image.altText: A young woman holds a swaddled infant in her arms as she sits on a patio leading into a dark home.

props.synopsis: The US used to spend more on international development than any other nation, but with Donald Trump and Elon Musk freezing USAID funding, people on the other side of the world are already dealing with some of the most devastating effects.

title.children: World's richest man wants poorest people cut off from crucial US aid

image.altText: A man speaking at a table.

props.synopsis: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth says Donald Trump is "supportive" of the AUKUS alliance, after Australia sent a $US500 million ($798 million) payment to Washington as part of it.

title.children: Trump 'supportive' of AUKUS, as Australia sends Washington $798m

image.altText: Police officer runs to make arrest in bush

props.synopsis: Queensland Police have charged three people with a litany of offences against representatives from space company Equatorial Launch Australia, including deprivation of liberty, threats and assault.

title.children: 'Dig a hole': Bush campers allegedly threaten space crew at knifepoint

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks at a press conference in brisbane

props.synopsis: The opposition leader says he is "happy to take questions" but won't appear at the National Press Club or offer specifics on his cost-cutting plans.

title.children: An election is nearing and Dutton doesn't seem to have a plan

image.altText: An image of dark clouds and intense rain falling on the landscape

props.synopsis: The long-awaited monsoon looks to officially kick in this weekend over northern Australia, helping to break up severe heatwave conditions plaguing much of the country. But the forecast rain is bad news for flood-ridden Queensland.

title.children: Heatwaves across the country set to ease as elusive monsoon rolls in

image.altText: Beach in Gaza

props.synopsis: After 15 months of war, children can still remember Gaza's beach side. But now, it has transformed into a vast landscape of destruction. Palestinians returning to their homes recall the better times.

title.children: Children once played by the ocean. Now Gaza's beaches are a 'sad' place

image.altText: A sad, older woman leaning against a wall.

props.synopsis: The town of Ingham and its surrounds went underwater after the Herbert River broke its banks. With the floodwater gone for now, they are left to see what's left.

title.children: 'People are in a bad way': Ingham left in chaos after flood

image.altText: Josh Inglis, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne.

props.synopsis: Steve Smith broke more records as the man once dubbed his protege, Marnus Labuschagne, edged closer to being dropped. Here are the quick hits from day two of the second Test in Galle.

title.children: Quick hits: Smith and Marnus's differing fortunes as Inglis faces wrath of quirky rule

image.altText: A woman with brown hair wearing a black jacket walks past TV cameras guided by a bald man in a black jacket

props.synopsis: The jury heard from Ms Kerr's friends, family and professional soccer teammates who spoke glowingly about her character, as the prosecution closed its case.

title.children: Sam Kerr is 'shy' and 'level-headed' off the pitch, friends tell racial harassment trial

image.altText: A chauffeur in a black suit opening the door of a black car.

props.synopsis: For years politicians have used their private travel paid for by the taxpayer in questionable ways — from chauffeuring pet pooches to a country home, to having petrol paid for while on holidays.

title.children: Chauffeuring dogs, paid petrol: Ministerial driver rules for state politicians

image.altText: Cynthia Erivo, in green make up and a witch's costume, next to Ariana Grande wearing pink.

props.synopsis: After being postponed twice due to the Los Angeles fires, the 30th Annual Critics Choice awards is ready to celebrate the best in film and TV over the last year.

title.children: Postponed Critics Choice Awards get underway in Los Angeles

image.altText: A woman facing the ocean holding her arms out with no one else around

props.synopsis: What if being single wasn't a problem to be solved but a state of bliss? For some women, living without their "other half" is the key to being complete.

title.children: 'No situationships, no dating apps, no exes': The women going 'Boysober'

image.altText: The graphic includes three polaroid photos of Eric Mercy with big groups of First Nations children

props.synopsis: A surfing legend is being remembered for his "big heart" after he took his own life in the late 90s. But in this community, his story isn't the only one. With the power of their connection and the ocean, his children are fighting to change that.

title.children: The tragic death of a surfing hero led a community to take action

image.altText: Three middle-aged men pictured in separate photos side by side

props.synopsis: The release of hostages and prisoners is a sign that the deal is moving forward, even as US and Israeli officials continue to call for the relocation of Gaza's population after the war.

title.children: Hamas names three more Israeli hostages to be freed as ceasefire deal holds

image.altText: A mother and daughter sit in front of their house

props.synopsis: There are barely any long-term rental properties available in the popular WA coastal town of Esperance. But can an abundance of holiday homes be blamed?

title.children: Airbnb was the 'lucrative' choice, but this family decided against it

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Leo Puglisi fronting a 6 News bulletin when he was 12.

props.synopsis: For as long as Leo Puglisi can remember, news has been his passion. But running a news channel from his bedroom while finishing high school isn't easy.

title.children: Starting a news channel at 11, Leo Puglisi juggles school and breaking news

image.altText: a graphic of a man being arrested with telegram logos flying across it

props.synopsis: In an Australian first, sanctions have been put on the online far-right extremist network Terrorgram. But if the US moves away from combating the problem under President Trump, could tackling emerging threats become harder?

title.children: No leaders, no uniforms but here's why Terrorgram is a global threat

image.altText: The Cook Islands Olympic team waves their flag on a boat in Paris

props.synopsis: Wellington is at odds with the Cook Islands over a looming new agreement with China and the former Pacific colony's plan to have its own passport.

title.children: Why has NZ 'bared its teeth' at its smaller, former Pacific colony?

image.altText: Palm trees stand in floodwaters.

props.synopsis: Already flood-ravaged communities are bracing for intense daily falls of up to 250mm and renewed river level rises from later today, with a severe weather warning still in place from Tully to Ayr.

title.children: North Queensland bracing for another onslaught of rain

image.altText: A "Pam the Bird" mural is seen on the side of an apartment building.

props.synopsis: It's the divisive artwork that has "blown people's minds away" and left others fuming. In court this week, police revealed the inner workings of the man allegedly behind "Pam the Bird".

title.children: The police mission to hunt down 'Pam the Bird'

image.altText: A red dirt road amongst a dry cattle station with dying shrubs

props.synopsis: Residents in the hottest parts of Australia say the extreme weather is making it impossible to work outdoors safely during the day, as thirsty camels create an additional challenge for cattle stations.

title.children: Outback temperatures too hot for electronics as residents 'try to survive'

image.altText: People walk past a tram and a bus stopped on a busy road under a blue sky.

props.synopsis: Law and order and the cost of living are front of mind for voters heading to the polls in the seats of Prahran and Werribee today, posing a major test for the Victorian Labor government.

title.children: Crime, hip pocket the key issues as Victorians cast votes in by-election

image.altText: Anthony Alabanese in a wide brimmed hat looks toward the camera with a woman out of the focus in the foreground

props.synopsis: Whichever party wins government at the upcoming federal election, the heightened focus on the Northern Territory in the lead-up is welcome proof its challenging issues aren’t just being swept under the rug.

title.children: Heightened federal focus shines spotlight on NT's challenges

image.altText: A sign on a building that says Harrods.

props.synopsis: Three former members of staff of London's Harrods store have accused Ali Fayed, brother of the chain's late boss Mohamed Al-Fayed, of sexual assault.

title.children: Surviving Al-Fayed brother becomes third accused of sexual abuse

image.altText: Fire union secretary Peter Marshall pictured in his uniform speaking at a rally.

props.synopsis: Fire union secretary Peter Marshall collected total pay of more than $985,000 last year after cashing in his leave entitlements, documents show.

title.children: Victorian fire union boss paid almost $1m due to leave entitlements

image.altText: A coach stands wide, instructs on tackling, with two players watching.

props.synopsis: NRLW players are more likely to hurt themselves or their opponents in a tackle than their male counterparts. Players and coaches explain why and what is being done to fix it.

title.children: Late starters, cross-code athletes tackle safety in women's rugby league

image.altText: People stand next to flowers and candles laid on the ground

props.synopsis: Sweden's government says it will seek to tighten gun laws in the wake of the country's deadliest mass shooting at an adult education centre where the attacker appeared to have used several of his own licensed rifles.

title.children: Sweden to tighten gun laws after deadliest mass shooting

image.altText: Aerial shot showing blue water, coastline and mangroves

props.synopsis: In an eight-course feast for the Perth Festival, audience members will be served dishes inspired by the flavours of WA's West Kimberley and get an immersive view of how food is caught and prepared.

title.children: Festival diners get up close to hunt for wild cattle in the Kimberley

image.altText: a woman's silhoutte in a window

props.synopsis: Authorities are inquiring after three Thai nationals say they feigned illness to avoid having their eggs harvested while being held captive in Georgia.

title.children: Investigation launched into human egg trafficking ring targeting Thai women

image.altText: Two RSL officials with what is believed to be a wartime diary.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide RSL is searching for the mystery owner of what is believed to be a World War I diary after it was left on its doorstep.

title.children: Search for origin of diary from WWI left on RSL's doorstep

image.altText: A young girl lines up for a plate of food

props.synopsis: Students are trying new foods as more schools are getting free lunches, and teachers say it's benefiting not just their bellies.

title.children: 'They're actually eating vegetables': How free school lunches are helping

image.altText: A man in a white beekeeping suit kneels with a large yellow box in front of beehives.

props.synopsis: Australian beekeepers are looking overseas to find chemical-free solutions to manage the world's deadliest bee parasite.

title.children: Heat could help kill deadly bee parasite varroa mite

props.synopsis: This week on If You're Listening, can one of the most divided, violent and vulnerable parts of the world find a way to fight back against Donald Trump's agenda? Matt Bevan takes a look.

title.children: If You're Listening: Can Donald Trump bully Panama into giving back its canal?
